title: Dialogs
description: Dialogs provide important prompts in a user flow.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Dialogs can require an action, communicate information, or help users accomplish a task. There are two types of dialogs: basic and full-screen.

contentChunks.footer:
1. Basic dialog
2. Full-screen dialog

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Resources

TypeLinkStatus
DesignDesign kit (Figma)Available
M2 guideline – DialogsAvailable
ImplementationMDC-AndroidAvailable
Jetpack ComposeAvailable
FlutterAvailable
WebPlanned

Takeaways

  • Dialogs focus user attention to ensure their content is addressed
  • Dialogs should be direct in communicating information and dedicated to completing a task
  • Dialogs should appear in response to a user task or an action, with relevant or contextual information
What's new

• Color: New color mappings and compatibility with dynamic color
  • Layout: Greater padding to account for the increased corner-radius and title size
  • Position: Option for custom basic dialog positioning.
  • Shape: Increased corner-radius 
  • Typography: Larger and darker headline

contentChunks.footer: New updates to color, layout, position, shape, and typography.
contentChunks.altText: Basic dialog with rounded corner, larger headline

Basic dialog color

Color values are implemented through design tokens. For design, this means working with color values that correspond with tokens. For implementation, a color value will be a token that references a value. Learn more about design tokens.

Contents

Usage
Anatomy
Basic dialog
Full-screen dialog
Responsive layout
Behavior
Usage

A dialog is a modal window that appears in front of app content to provide critical information or ask for a decision. Dialogs disable all app functionality when they appear, and remain on screen until confirmed, dismissed, or a required action has been taken.

Dialogs are purposefully interruptive, so they should be used sparingly. A less disruptive alternative is to use a menu, which provides options without interrupting a user’s experience.

contentChunks.footer: Use dialogs for prompts that block an app’s normal operation, and for critical information that requires a specific user task, decision, or acknowledgement.
contentChunks.altText: Dialog in front of app content

contentChunks.footer: Don’t use dialogs for low- or medium-priority information. Instead, use a banner (which can be dismissed) or snackbar (which disappears automatically).
contentChunks.altText: Low priority dialog in front of app content
Diagram of basic and full-screen dialogs

contentChunks.htmlValue:
There are two types of dialogs

  1. Basic dialog
  2. Full-screen dialog
Anatomy
Basic dialog

contentChunks.footer:
1. Container
2. Icon (optional)
3. Headline (optional)
4. Supporting text
5. Divider (optional)
6. Actions

contentChunks.altText: Diagram of 7 elements of basic dialog

contentChunks.htmlValue: Full-screen dialog

contentChunks.footer:
1. Container
2. Header region
3. Close affordance
4. Headline (optional)
5. Action
6. Divider (optional)

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Container and scrim

Dialog containers appear above other screen elements and hold the dialog’s headline, text, buttons, and list items.

To focus attention on the dialog, surfaces behind the container are scrimmed with a temporary overlay to make them less prominent.

contentChunks.footer: Basic dialogs appear over a background scrim.
contentChunks.altText: Basic dialog shown above a scrim overlay that reduces the prominence of the background elements

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Headline (optional)

A dialog’s purpose should be communicated by its headline and buttons or actionable items.

Headlines should:

  • Contain a brief and clear statement or question
  • Avoid apologies (Sorry for the interruption), extra alarm (Warning!), or ambiguity (Are you sure?)

contentChunks.footer: This dialog title poses a specific question, concisely explains what’s involved in the request, and provides clear actions.
Don’t use dialog titles that pose an ambiguous question.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Headlines should always be succinct. They can wrap to a second line if necessary, and be truncated.

In full-screen dialogs, long headlines or headlines of variable lengths (such as translations), can be placed in the content area instead of the app bar.

contentChunks.footer: Avoid placing long headlines in a full-screen dialog’s top app bar (1), as the truncated text may lead to misunderstanding.
contentChunks.altText: Example full-screen dialog with long headline

contentChunks.footer: Find ways to shorten app bar text, and place longer headlines into the content area (1) of a full-screen dialog.
contentChunks.altText: Example full-screen dialog with short headline

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Buttons

Dialog actions are most often represented as buttons and allow users to confirm, dismiss, or acknowledge something.

Confirming actions are aligned to the ending side of the screen with dismissive actions on the leading side of the confirming action. For layouts using left-to-right languages, this means the confirming action is placed on the right, with the dismissing action to its left. This placement is reversed for right-to-left languages.

contentChunks.footer: Disable confirming actions (1) until a choice is made. Dismissive actions are never disabled.
Don’t place dismissive actions (1) to the right of confirming actions. Instead, place them to the left of confirming actions.
A single action may be provided only if it’s an acknowledgement.
Avoid presenting users with unclear choices. “Cancel” doesn't make sense here because no clear action is proposed.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Dialogs should contain a maximum of two actions.

  • If a single action is provided, it must be an acknowledgement action.
  • If two actions are provided, one must be a confirming action, and the other a dismissing action.

contentChunks.footer: Display 2 text buttons next to one another.
Stacked buttons accommodate longer button text but take up more room. Confirming actions appear above dismissive actions.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Providing a third action, such as “Learn more,” is not recommended as it navigates the user away from the dialog, leaving the dialog task unfinished.

Rather than adding a third action, an inline expansion can display more information. If more extensive information is needed, provide it prior to entering the dialog.

contentChunks.footer: The “Learn more” action (1) navigates away from this dialog, potentially leaving it in an indeterminate state.
contentChunks.altText: Example of dialog with 3 text buttons

contentChunks.htmlValue: Basic dialog
Basic dialogs interrupt users with urgent information, details, or actions. Common use cases for basic dialogs include alerts, quick selection, and confirmation.

contentChunks.footer: Basic dialogs require the user to take action before it will close.
contentChunks.altText: Example of basic dialog action request

contentChunks.footer: Basic dialogs can give users the ability to provide confirmation of a choice before committing to it.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Basic dialogs often appear as alerts or lists, but may also use a variety of layouts and component combinations, including lists, date pickers, and time pickers.

contentChunks.footer: Date picker dialogs allow users to tap a date, then confirm it by tapping “OK.”
Time picker dialogs allow users to move the clock hand and then confirm by tapping “OK.”

contentChunks.htmlValue: Full-screen dialog

Full-screen dialogs fill the entire screen, containing actions that require a series of tasks to complete. One example is creating a calendar entry with the event title, date, location, and time.

Because they take up the entire screen, full-screen dialogs are the only dialogs over which other dialogs can appear.

Use a container transform pattern to transition a FAB into a full-screen dialog.

contentChunks.footer: Full-screen dialogs contain actions that require a series of tasks to complete.

contentChunks.htmlValue: When a full-screen dialog is closed without being saved, a modal dialog appears in front of it to confirm selections should be discarded without saving changes.

contentChunks.footer: Full-screen dialogs contain actions that require a series of tasks to complete.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Full-screen dialogs may be used for content or tasks that meet any of these criteria:

  • Dialogs that include components which require keyboard input, such as form fields
  • When changes aren’t saved instantly
  • When components within the dialog open additional dialogs

Full-screen dialogs are for mobile devices only. For tablet or desktop, use a modal dialog.

Saving selections

To save a selection in a full-screen dialog, the user taps “Save.” To discard all changes and exit, the user taps the “X” icon or “Back” button.

Confirmation

The confirmation action is disabled until all mandatory fields are filled. Use descriptive verbs such as “Save,” “Send,” “Share,” “Update,” or “Create.” Don’t use vague terms such as “Done,” “OK” or “Close.”

If no changes have been made, the dialog closes and no discard confirmation is required

If the user has made changes, the user is prompted to confirm the discard action.

contentChunks.footer: A “Close” button (1) is vague because it does not indicate whether changes will be saved or discarded.
contentChunks.altText: Example of full-screen dialog with close button

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Dialog windows

Launching a full-screen dialog temporarily resets the app’s perceived elevation, allowing simple menus or dialogs to appear above the full-screen dialog. They cover the screen and don’t appear as a floating modal window.

Navigation

Because full-screen dialogs can only be completed, dismissed, or closed, the close “X” icon button should be the only navigation option in the top app bar.
Responsive layout

When scaling layouts for larger screens, adjust a dialog’s visual presentation by setting minimum and maximum values for margins, padding, and container dimensions.

Dialogs should maintain a minimum 48dp distance from the leading and trailing edges of a screen. On small screens, dialogs scale vertically until reaching 48dp from the screen’s top and bottom edge. On larger displays, dialogs can increase in size to a maximum width of 560dp and maintain a distance of 56dp from the edges of a screen. When a dialog reaches the maximum width, it expands or contracts vertically to support content, up to a maximum height of 560dp.

contentChunks.footer: Dialogs can reach a maximum height and width of 560dp on large screens.
contentChunks.altText: Example of dialog in desktop layout

contentChunks.htmlValue: Dialogs can also swap types as a screen size changes. For example, a full-screen dialog can change into a simple dialog at larger breakpoints.

contentChunks.footer: 1. Full-screen dialog on mobile. 2. Dialog on a tablet.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Tablet

Basic dialogs appear in a center position by default, but their position can be overridden to provide a more ergonomic experience.

contentChunks.footer: Dialog custom positioned on the right side of the screen
contentChunks.altText: Basic dialog on tablet photos app

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Desktop

Desktop dialogs are modal windows above a scrim. This puts the dialog at the forefront of the user's view, calling attention to the action prompted in the dialog.

contentChunks.footer: Desktop dialogs call attention to the required action.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Large screen

Basic dialogs can be custom-positioned anywhere on the screen. Positions should continue to respect a margin to prevent edge collision.

contentChunks.footer: Custom placement area for basic dialogs that respects a 56dp margin from the edges of the screen.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Behavior

Appearing

Dialogs appear without warning, requiring users to stop their current task. They should be used sparingly, as not every choice or setting warrants interruption.

Dialogs use an enter and exit transition pattern to appear on screen.

contentChunks.footer: Dialogs appear without warning, entering and exiting the screen in a fade-transition pattern.
contentChunks.altText: Dialog entering and exiting screen using fade transition

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Position

Dialogs retain focus until dismissed or an action has been taken, such as choosing a setting. They shouldn’t be obscured by other elements or appear partially on screen, with the exception of full-screen dialogs.

contentChunks.footer: Dialogs shouldn’t be obscured by other elements except for full-screen dialogs.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Scrolling

Most dialog content should avoid scrolling. Even when scrolling is required, the dialog title is pinned at the top, with buttons pinned at the bottom. This ensures selected content remains visible alongside the title and buttons, even upon scroll.

Dialogs don’t scroll with elements outside of the dialog, such as the background.

contentChunks.footer: When viewing a scrollable list of options, the dialog title and buttons remain fixed.
contentChunks.altText: Example of fixed dialog title and buttons

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Dismissing

To close a dialog used as an alert, one of its actions must be selected.

Other dialogs may be dismissed by:

  • Tapping a Cancel button, if one is shown
  • Selecting an actionable list item
  • Pressing the keyboard Esc key
  • Tapping the scrim (Android, iOS)
  • Tapping the Android system Back button
  • Using another standard cancel or escape action, such as iOS VoiceOver escape gesture

If the user’s ability to dismiss a dialog is disabled, the user must choose a dialog action to proceed.

contentChunks.footer: Dismissing a dialog alert involves selecting an action.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
When a dialog box is dismissed, the following transitions occur:

  • The dialog box fades out
  • The background scrim fades out

contentChunks.footer: When dismissed, a dialog box fades out along with the background scrim.
contentChunks.altText: Example of dialog box fading out

contentChunks.htmlValue: Use cases

Users should be able to 

  • Open and close a dialog
  • Provide and submit other inputs if the dialog is interactive, such as a text field or selectable list
  • Scroll the dialog to access all of its contents if that content extends beyond the container of the dialog
Interaction & style

Dialogs are purposefully interruptive. This means they appear in front of app content and disrupt the flow of content for users who may, for example, be using a screen reader to navigate the page.

As such, dialogs should be used sparingly and only to provide critical information. Less critical information should be presented in a non-blocking way within the flow of app content.

contentChunks.footer: Present non-critical information using other UI within the flow of app content
Avoid putting non-critical information in a dialog

contentChunks.htmlValue: Elements contained in dialogs

Because dialogs can contain various elements within them, refer to the relevant accessibility guidelines for each element. Some common examples include:

  1. Typography
  2. Text fields
  3. Buttons

contentChunks.footer: Full-screen dialogs can contain various elements such as (1) typography, (2) text fields, and (3) buttons, which each may have their own accessibility guidelines.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Keyboard navigation

KeysActions
TabFocus lands on the next interactive element contained in the dialog, or the first element if focus is currently on the last element
Shift + Tab
Focus lands on the previous interactive element contained in the dialog, or the last element if focus is currently on the first element
Space / Enter
Triggers or commits the action of the focused element
Escape
Closes the dialog
Initial focus
When a dialog appears, focus should automatically land on the first interactive element within the dialog.

contentChunks.footer: Initial focus lands on the first interactive element within a dialog. The tab key moves focus through the next interactive elements in a cycle.
The shift and tab keys together move focus in the opposite direction. The space or enter key triggers or commits the action of the focused element.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Labeling elements
The accessibility label for a dialog is typically the same as the dialog’s title or headline.

contentChunks.footer: An alert dialog whose title is used for its accessibilty label.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Components contained within the dialog, such as buttons, should be labeled according to the guidelines specific to those components.

For common examples, see:

  • Buttons
  • Text fields

contentChunks.footer: A full-screen dialog with a button and textfields labeled
